fields.summary: As a project manager I want to see and manage dependencies between several portfolio plans.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-332].
  {panel}

When I create a new plan and import issues into that plan, I want any story points that were defined in my issues to carry over into my new plan.

*Current behavior*
When a user creates a new plan in JIRA Portfolio and proceeds to import issues into the plan, any story points that were included on the original issue do not show up in the plan.

*Requested behavior*
When a user creates a new plan in JIRA Portfolio and proceeds to import issues into the plan, any story points that were included on the original issue show up in the plan.
fields.summary: When importing issues from JIRA, story points should carry over

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-151].
  {panel}

I created 3 Release versions in a JIRA Portfolio plan.

Next I created a release stream called "Release Stream A"

When I created the stream, it asked if I wanted to move the existing Releases into the new stream or leave them in the default stream. I chose to leave them in default stream, but now I want to move 2 of the 3 into the "Release Stream A" and I can't.

Could you please implement this suggestion on a further release?

Thanks,
[~berntx]

h3. Problem Definition
In cases where the same team works on different projects, managing that is not optimal. For example, any modifications must be replicated across all projects they belong to, which is susceptible to error.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add the ability to share teams across multiple projects

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-55].
  {panel}

{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 24 March 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting! This issue is being addressed as part of the all new Portfolio live plans, which feature an entirely overhauled and more seamless integration model with JIRA Software / Agile. Live plans are currently available as a labs feature for both Server* and Cloud, so you can start evaluating them without any risk of impacting existing Portfolio plans. They are not yet feature-complete, we're working on bringing all major capabilities of standard plans back into live plans on top of the new integration model before we graduate live plans out of labs and make them the new standard way of working. 
Please check out this blog for a summary and short videos of how the top-voted suggestions are being addressed with live plans: [Top 10 suggestions addressed in live plans|http://blogs.atlassian.com/2016/03/10-user-suggestions-addressed-in-portfolio-for-jira/] and join our [Portfolio Pioneers LinkedIn group|https://www.linkedin.com/groups/7018171] to discuss feedback and best practices!
 
Thanks,
Martin Suntinger
[msuntinger@atlassian.com|mailto:msuntinger@atlassian.com]
Principal Product Manager, Portfolio for JIRA
 
^*The live plans labs feature is available with Portfolio for JIRA 1.12 or higher. It is compatible with JIRA Software 7.0.5 or higher, and JIRA 6.3 or higher, in association with JIRA Agile 6.7.12 or higher.^
{panel}

Currently, resources cannot be shared between plans. As the doc explains:

"plans are completely logically separate and do not consider in any way data from other plans. This means, that the same user could be booked in parallel plans for the same time slot."

Here are some unfortunate consequences:

* JPO could not be used by an organization of any size for global resource planning.
* If one is trying to use JPO for an area with a number of independent projects and shared resources, there is no good solution:
** If you throw everything into one big plan, you make "plan updates" problematic, since the results affect the entire plan and may need to be coordinated with many different people who are supposed to be working independently of each other - probably impractical. Furthermore, by mixing independent projects into one plan, you make the plan too "big" for comfort. (But it is true that JPO offers features like release streams and initiatives that help here. However, it looks like JPO might provide sub-plan objects like release streams to work around the problem that plans have to be bigger than they naturally would be, due to the fact that resource sharing is not possible. ).
** If you create separate plans, you have problems allocating resources. You have to be careful to look at how a person is allocated in each plan to make sure the allocation doesn't exceed his total available hours. And you have make arrangements for him not being overbooked for a given period of time. All this without JPO support.

I think the solution is to move the "People" feature out of the plan and into a bigger object - e.g. "Organization". Here one would specify people and allocate them for given periods of time to plans. The plans would then have to work with the resource constraints handed down from the organization.
fields.summary: Resources should be shared between plans.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-475].
  {panel}

I would like to use a Portfolio plan to define a single set of Releases and be able to easily spread this information on a number of JIRA projects.

Today, we can import JIRA Versions to create Portfolio Releases or link Versions to Releases.
In a plan, backlog items are dispatched across these Releases, but we can only "apply" the release to a JIRA issue if a corresponding Version exists in corresponding JIRA project.

it would be good if the *"Apply updates to projects" could automatically create Versions* required, perhaps asking confirmation to the user, *whenever no existing version matches the release* (name, start/end) being applied. The advantage would be to save considerable time as one can avoid defining all the Versions in all my source JIRA projects
fields.summary: Create JIRA Versions from Portfolio Releases with "apply updates to projects"
Advanced description editing (Wiki markup for description)

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-223].
  {panel}

h4. Problem Definition
At the moment, Epic can only be assigned to a single team. The same rule applied to team assignment in initiative as well. For each epic (broken down from initiative) or story (broken down from epic), only one team can be assigned to it.

h4. Suggested Solution
It would be great to have the option to allow epic / initiative assignment to multiple teams and resources.
fields.summary: Allow epic assignment to multiple teams and resources

{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 24 March 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting! This issue is being addressed as part of the all new Portfolio live plans, which feature an entirely overhauled and more seamless integration model with JIRA Software / Agile. Live plans are currently available as a labs feature for both Server* and Cloud, so you can start evaluating them without any risk of impacting existing Portfolio plans. They are not yet feature-complete, we're working on bringing all major capabilities of standard plans back into live plans on top of the new integration model before we graduate live plans out of labs and make them the new standard way of working. 
Please check out this blog for a summary and short videos of how the top-voted suggestions are being addressed with live plans: [Top 10 suggestions addressed in live plans|http://blogs.atlassian.com/2016/03/10-user-suggestions-addressed-in-portfolio-for-jira/] and join our [Portfolio Pioneers LinkedIn group|https://www.linkedin.com/groups/7018171] to discuss feedback and best practices!
 
Thanks,
Martin Suntinger
[msuntinger@atlassian.com|mailto:msuntinger@atlassian.com]
Principal Product Manager, Portfolio for JIRA
 
^*The live plans labs feature is available with Portfolio for JIRA 1.12 or higher. It is compatible with JIRA Software 7.0.5 or higher, and JIRA 6.3 or higher, in association with JIRA Agile 6.7.12 or higher.^
{panel}

When pushing update via *Plan > Apply updates to project/s*, despite all items under Update linked elements are selected, the Epic-Story links are not updated.

Steps to reproduce:
* Import Story and Epics from JIRA
* Create new Epic and corresponding JIRA Epic using Portfolio
* Move existing Story under new Epic using Portfolio
* Click Plan > Apply updates to projects/s

Current Behaviour
* New JIRA Epic does not link with the JIRA Story
* The JIRA Story still links with original JIRA Epic

Expected Behaviour
* The JIRA Story should now linked with the new JIRA Epic created from Portfolio
fields.summary: "Apply update to projects" should provide an option to sync Epic/Story relationships
Update plan from date: Allow to show only the changes in the dialog

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-136].
  {panel}

[MIGRATED from uservoice]

I am very impressed by the scope of what your product brings to the planning process. However, I believe that if an EPIC is to be considering the primary top level planning unit, then I think your product is missing one important aspect - the facility to apply business value ratings to EPICS!

By this I mean having a facility to apply a business influence/value ratings to an EPIC - ideally across several different rating factors.

Examples of these business value attributes include: 
* Strategic value 
* Revenue influence 
* Cost of Sale influence 
* Cost of ownership influence 
* Risk

Put simply you could imagine having a facility to: 
* Define one or more business rating attributes 
* At an EPIC level allow numeric values to be assigned against each attribute 
* Extend your roadmap time view to include a horizontal band that shows how much business value is being delivered over time.
fields.summary: Applying business value ratings to EPICS

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-85].
  {panel}

It would be helpful to support financial calculations (projected/actual project costs) that Jira would support the following: 

1 - At role level, the ability to define a generalized rate for each role and leverage that for calculations/reports for projected project costs. 

2 - At the user level, the ability to define a user's hourly rate and leverage that for calculations/reports for actual project costs.

These two features would help this process out tremendously.
fields.summary: Financial Reporting Support (Group, User Levels)
Highlight Initiatives/Epics/Stories
Team-specific non-working days

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-166].
  {panel}

h3. Steps to reproduce:

# Create two distinct Plans.
# Create a JIRA group {{read-plan}} and add a user to this group.
# In the Portfolio Global Permission, add the group {{read-plan}} in the permission {{JIRA Portfolio Viewer}}
# Open the both Plans, the permission should be shown as Read-only.
# Open one of the Plans, and edit Permissions at: Plan >> Configure >> Permissions.
# Add the group {{read-plan}} as "Editor".
# Test the permissions of the Plans, both plans will still being viewed as read-only.

h3. Expected Behaviour:

The permission configured directly in the Plan, should overwrite the Global Permission, giving the ability to grant granular permission levels depending on the Plan.

As a side note, this configuration will work if configured reverse, granting User permission in the Global permission, and then view permission in the plan, the Global Permission will respect the more restrictive.

If the user doesn't have any Global permission and you add a Plan permission, the plan permission isn't considered.
fields.summary: Plan level permissions should take precedence over global permission settings

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-112].
  {panel}

Scenario: 
For each release stream, I have several teams that can potentially work on it, others are dedicated towards other streams. 

Yet, i cannot assign these teams at the level of a release stream. I need to go through all backlog items and assign them individually. Since with epics (without child stories) I cannot assign multiple teams unless its on auto-calculate, it is impossible for these cases to assign exactly the right teams that are dedicated to my stream of work. 

Suggested solution: Allow to set assignable teams for a release stream (this should be fully optional, if nothing it set, any team can work on any release stream). When this is set, the backlog items can be left to "Calculate" on the team field and the right teams get picked based on the preselection. Also, if I change it on stream level and dedicate another team to a release stream, this change reflects implicitly on all backlog items.
fields.summary: Limit assignable teams for a release stream
Horizontal scrolling using the magic mouse on the Mac is not possible
Import from MS Project
When a story is closed and then re-opened in Jira, it should not drop out of Portfolio
percentage bar when re-calculating

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-268].
  {panel}

The use case we frequently have is: 
- 2 or more team members should be scheduled to work on one task, at the same time (if possible). 

In the same way that Portfolio can create and link one JIRA issue per stage, it would be great to have one issue per skill, with one dedicated assignee each. Portfolio should then try to schedule these at the same time, just like it does for Epic bundles now. 

What we do at the moment is create 2 stories/issues, and put them into the same release, and hope they get scheduled at the same time. This kind of works, but puts some wrong functionality in the release stream.
fields.summary: Create and link multiple JIRA issues per story, one for each skill

^*The live plans labs feature is available with Portfolio for JIRA 1.12 or higher. It is compatible with JIRA Software 7.0.5 or higher, and JIRA 6.3 or higher, in association with JIRA Agile 6.7.12 or higher.^

Here are the steps I follow:

1. Create an Epic in JIRA Portfolio.
2. Import some Stories from JIRA that have no Epic link and make them children of the Epic in Portfolio.
3. Within Portfolio, create an issue for the Epic.

Actual result - The Epic is created but has no links to it's child stories in JIRA.
Desired result - The new Epic issue should be linked to the existing Story issues in JIRA.

I hope that makes sense! If not then please let me know and I'll try to provide further clarification.
fields.summary: Creating Epics where issues already exist for Stories
As a stream manager I want to have the option to link a stream strictly to a jira project.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-424].
  {panel}

*Story*
As planners and users, we need to be able to see issue keys in the graphical schedule, so that we can easily identify the issues in the schedule.

This is really hard at the moment, as our teams always refer to issues by key, not summary. 

The schedule, which is a huge part of the value of Portfolio, is not very useful to us without this, and is hampering adoption.

*Suggested solution*
- Add a 'Show issue links' checkbox in the cog on the bottom-right (or make it a global configuration option).
- This checkbox would only be effective in Stories, Epics or Initiatives modes in the graphical schedule.
- If the checkbox is ticked, the issue summaries are prefixed with the issue key if a link exists, and the link points to the JIRA issue.

I would like to see the issue links directly in the bar representing the story/epic/initiative, not in the mouseover as that would mean hovering over each issue to identify it.
fields.summary: Show issue keys/links in graphical schedule
Allow comments on stories created in Portfolio

WORSE, when I apply updates to JIRA Portfolio it goes as sets the old fixVersion value back on the issues.
fields.summary: Auto-update/Sync versions as it is done for titles, estimates, descriptions
Import Issues: Search and filter for issues dynamically rather than having to use saved filters

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-186].
  {panel}

Progress Stories In Backlog are not marked in red when tracking exceeds the original estimation

In the first versions of the JIRA portfolio plugin  when  in a Story or Epic  the tracking hours exceed the original estimation the progress bar was labeled/marked in red . Now seems this feature is not available .  (Or at least I'm not able to see this now)

In our company (Ebay Enterprise) this is a derired feature . 
It is possible to fix this ? or at least provide a way to configure this?
fields.summary: Show progress of Stories in Backlog as red when tracking exceeds the original estimation
Synchronize Portfolio Estimate with Time Tracking in JIRA Issue

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-91].
  {panel}

We track target (what the business wants), estimated (what the teams think can be achieved) & actual (what occured) dates for our projects. We do this for key milestones which are critical (especially as we operate in a regulated market).

It would be great if we could:
1) Define the target dates for milestones (ideally we could define milestones for projects / initiatives etc)
2) have estimates created based on planning in Portfolio
3) actuals be recorded based on those milestones being met
fields.summary: Target, Estimate & Actual dates
Ability to copy backlog items
JIRA Portfolio "Apply updates to project/s" should never overwrite fields with blank values.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-264].
  {panel}

The first 'Update from date...' that was run after issues were imported wanted to update the status (Issue JPO-263) and the estimated time.
For the issues that were already complete, it was going to set the estimated time to 0 hours. Not wanting to apply these values to the completed issues, I only selected the status for updating, unchecking all other fields.

This updated the status. I then tried to run the 'Update from date..' again now that the completed items were no longer listed. I intended to pull in the estimated time changes, but the changes were no longer listed. 

This was frustrating and I could not find a way to get the current estimate time into Portfolio. Even new changes made to the 'original time estimate' and 'remaining time estimate' would not appear. I think this is because the occurred in the same day as the last update, but I don't know the logic it uses for finding changes.
fields.summary: Allow running 'Update from date...' sequentially for different fields
Ability to reorder Epics by moving its Initiative
Allow issue linking across projects
Synchronize the team name with a field in JIRA

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-456].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Currently it is not possible to define resource allocation with percentage ratio and based on the time that can commit.

h3. Suggested Solution
It would be great if we are able to allocate a resource (person) and then the percentage of time they could be used on a story/epic per line item in portfolio.
fields.summary: resource allocation with percentage
Allow JIRA search navigator to see JIRA Portfolio statuses
drop-down filtering on initiatives
issues that block issues within the portfolio should be automatically added to the portfolio.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-275].
  {panel}

I imported all epics and stories from JIRA.

When push update via *Plan > Apply updates to project/s*, despite all items under *Update linked elements* are selected, the Epic-Story links are not updated.

Steps to reproduce:
* Import Story and Epics from JIRA
* Create new Epic and corresponding JIRA Epic using Portfolio
* Move existing Story under new Epic using Portfolio
* Click Plan > Apply updates to projects/s

Current Behaviour
* New JIRA Epic does not link with the JIRA Story
* The JIRA Story still links with original JIRA Epic

Expected Behaviour
* The JIRA Story should now linked with the new JIRA Epic created from Portfolio

(We are using Atlassian Cloud)
fields.summary: When push update to project, Epic-Story linkage is not updated based on Portfolio Plan
Provide a configuration option in 'Update from date' dialog that allows items with no remaining estimate to remain open

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-100].
  {panel}

Currently, Jira Portfolio simply forces the start of the next version to be after the current version

This doesn't make sense because:

1. Developers can work across versions concurrently, e.g. some developers in the team are finalising 1.1 while other developers are starting 1.2, and some might even be working on 1.3 or beyond

2. Project managers and Designers need to start their planning and design on a new version before developers and we want to allocate their time on the epics as well
fields.summary: Versions should be able to run concurrently
Resizable columns
Bulk Actions

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-56].
  {panel}

For programs / portfolios with multiple projects underneath, there should be a way to easily add existing Jira projects into a plan created within the portfolio module. 

By selecting an existing project for import users would be able to select the associated boards (scrum/kanban/etc...) of that project, and their associated backlog items they wish to pull into the plan.

This would automatically create the structure of the roadmap, which would be adjusted automatically as items are completed (or not), dates extended (or not), etc... that is being managed via the boards themselves.

In this way the Portfolio module would provide the following structure to a program with multiple projects:

- Overall portfolio
    - Project 1
       - Project 1's backlog items (epics, stories, bugs) / sprints
    - Project 2
       - Project 2's backlog items (epics, stories, bugs) / sprints
    - Project 3
       - Project 3's backlog items (epics, stories, bugs) /sprints
- Overall portfolio roadmap
   - Project 1 specific roadmap
   - Project 2 specific roadmap
   - Project 3 specific roadmap

This would remove duplication of effort between the Agile and Portfolio module, and simplify the process to create a portfolio's structure.
fields.summary: Add the ability to import projects, and their underlying structure into a portfolio plan
Allow to add custom columns to backlog
JIRA Portfolio should have a separate log file
Drag and drop your planning like Confluence Roadmap
Define if epics within an initiative are spread across teams or limited
Visibility of dependencies
Allow dependent Stories to be in same Sprint

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-291].
  {panel}

Today the only way to achieve that is to look over the reports and check initiatives and epics separately.

I'd like to have a schedule report with the following structure:
- Initiative
-- Epics
fields.summary: Add a schedule report view based Epics per Initiative
force assignment stories into a release
Support archiving of releases
Allow individual releases priorization among different streams
Clicking of release dots in timeline should provide additional information about the release
Allow work schemes or repeating non-working days for team members

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-331].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Currently it is possible to synchronize the estimation between *JIRA Agile* and *JIRA Portfolio* when the same field is used for estimation on both. As it is possible to estimate using a custom field in *JIRA Agile* - but not in *JIRA Portfolio* - the synchronization will not work.

Also, different teams may use different estimates on different *Plans*, which is not something currently possible with JIRA Portfolio.

h3. Suggested Solution
* JIRA Portfolio would have a default *Estimation*.
* The *Estimation* could be configured per plan.
* The *Estimation* would accept values of "Number" custom fields.
fields.summary: As a project manager, I want to estimate using custom fields

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-204].
  {panel}

I saw JPO-75, but it was not clear as to what behaviour it was specifically related to. In 1.8.4 this behaviour appears to be present through the "Import Issues" button and as such is Resolved; unless I have misunderstood?

As Epics can be added through JIRA Agile but they don't appear until a manual "Import Issues" is performed, in my opinion I believe there is a significant opportunity for Epics to be missed. 

Ideally, the regular "Update from date..." operation would also identify new Epics in the Project(s) and suggest importing them into the plan. This provides a cue for a Product Owner to:
* Review the validity of those Epics
* Question the origin of those Epics (E.g. in organisations where project input should be funnelled through the PO).
* Identify the priority of those new Epics and re-plan accordingly.

Apologies if I have misunderstood Portfolio or it's behaviour.

Many Thanks,
Alex
fields.summary: Suggest import of new JIRA Agile Epics when using "Update from date..."
Allow hiding weekends in the chart

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-53].
  {panel}

It would be great to keep the plan in sync with JIRA in a similar fashion that JIRA Structure took.
* automatically add items to the plan when added or linked to Epic/Story
* add or remove based on saved filter or JQL
* allow to include dependent or linked issues in the import

This would be a great help for quite common scenario where there already is a complex hierarchy in JIRA created by Stories in Epic as well as issue links, that needs to get transferred (and kept in sync!) to JIRA Portfolio.

Thanks for your consideration!
fields.summary: Extending Import/Synchronization options
Add support for importing Epics from JIRA Agile into JIRA Portfolio
Dependencies as Issue Links
